clinical_study.brief_title: Intraoperative Pauses in Relation to Stress Assessment Among Surgeons
clinical_study.official_title: Intraoperative Pauses in Relation to Stress Assessment Among Surgeons

brief_summary.textblock: Intraoperative stress among the surgical team can be a threat to patient safety and good teamwork. During surgery, surgeons often work under stressful conditions. Reducing intraoperative stress for surgeons could benefit surgeons and subsequently patients. Based on the hypothesis that an intraoperative pause including a sugar-containing drink would decrease surgeon's stress levels, the aim of this study is to compare stress levels, in relation to intraoperative stress and how this is affected by a pause including a sugar-containing drink in simulated operations.

detailed_description.textblock: A randomized controlled cross-over trial was conducted in a simulator environment. Primary endpoint was intra-individual change in salivary cortisol between simulations with or without a pause including a sugar containing drink. Secondary endpoints were change in heart rate, change in self-perceived stress measured by the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), and experience of the intraoperative pause.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: A randomized controlled cross-over trial was conducted in a simulator environment

primary_outcome.description: Intra-individual change in salivary cortisol between simulations with or without a pause including a sugar containing drink.

secondary_outcome.description: Change in heart rate during surgery

measured by the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) Each STAI item is given a weighted score of 1 to 4. A rating of 4 indicates the presence of a high level of anxiety for ten S-Anxiety items and eleven T-Anxiety items. A high rating indicates the absence of anxiety for the remaining ten S-Anxiety items and nine T-Anxiety items.
Questionnaire with self-experience questions - no scale

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Surgeon within five years of specialization with basic laparoscopic skills, able to perform an appendectomy
Exclusion Criteria:
- diabetes
- Addison's disease
- medication with steroids or medication that affect heart rate (beta-blockers, calcium antagonists, antiarrhythmics, and digitalis) Smoking
